job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Columbus, OH
pros: Mt Carmel was my very first hospital system for employment back in 2016. I started as an EDT and continued working there after receiving my RN license. For a short period I left and went to another hospital system, but continued to keep a contingent position with Mt Carmel as a flex nurse. I'm so happy I did! Their values at Mt Carmel, compensation, and attention to detail regarding educating staff and putting appropriate policies and procedures in place are unsurpassed. I'm moving out of state and sadly I will be leaving Mt Carmel. I'm thankful for the confidence and knowledge I have gained as a nurse working for Mt Carmel. Hospitals are NOT perfect but Mt Carmel wholeheartedly tries to be the best hospital system for their staff and patients.
cons: Some of the bigger EDs and hospitals can be very busy. And at times it can be a little daunting. MCE being a trauma hospital gets very chaotic and the community in that area depends on this big hospital. I think the ED can use a revamp to better support the high volume of patients and workflow for the department.

review_title: Good place to build up skills
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Columbus, OH
pros: Very nice, friendly and supportive coworkers! PTO is fast and easy to accrue. Flexible scheduling and can block schedule which is a huge perk. Building up lots of skills so you'll be better prepared to be a RN if you continue school.
cons: Not unionized - always understaffed. and they pay employees of the same rank differently which isn't fair. Doctors and nurses are leaving in droves. Half of the nurses on the units are travelers or have very little experience. No sick leave which means you have to use your PTO and you lose points. Pay is poor compared to non-hospital LPN positions.

review_title: Worst Situation in My Entire Career - Kudos to the Nurses!
pros:
The nurses/techs/general staff are all incredible, there's little drama (unless management related). Immediate management tries to pitch in and help each other although it's nearly impossible.
Immediate management is really good, there's new people in there who care about employees.
Pay is decent, a bit on the low side but not terribly.
cons:
In my nine years as a medic, I've worked some rough jobs. It's to be expected, especially in a trauma situation. The stress from Mt. Carmel comes from management however. I was so very thankful to walk away, although I did miss my nurses/techs.
- Decisions made can put your licensure at risk. When you have 70 patients to tech for, or 11 critical patients (as a nurse), you can't do it all. 

- You will not get any breaks at all. They say you will get your legal lunch break, you will not after orientation. Lunch is unpaid, meaning they get an extra thirty minutes of work for free. They also will write you up if you don't lie and say you got a break.

- It is very disorganized. I would get points for days I wasn't scheduled, PTO disappeared, paycheck disappeared. I was scheduled for classes but no one would tell me where to go or when it was. I assume this is because of the huge turnover.

- Management doesn't listen to staff. They continue adding more and more tasks to the ED without helping. They often threatened to take away life-saving equipment if something broke. Accidents happen, but that equipment can save a life.

-It is extremely dirty. There was a trauma cart that sat in front of patients for 12 hours with blood and worse all over it. One of many times. Again, short staffed.

- Pay varies based on favoritism, so do raises.

job_title: Manager, Quality Assurance in Columbus, OH
pros: Colleagues, direct care staff, some good people.
cons: Company is so top heavy. Complaints to HR regarding toxic and abusive behavior go unaddressed, even when there is a pattern.

cons: Long hours and so so medical benefits

review_title: ED RN at Mt Carmel East
pros: Recruiters are very helpful and responsive, quick process to get into work (1-2 weeks) and start orientation. Unit education was incredibly beneficial.
cons: Terrible unit management, very backwards with many processes, no cohesion through the hospital or the health system. Look at the lawsuits against this health system: Dr. Husel, Survival Flight, legionaries outbreak at multiple locations (hospitals and college of nursing). You will be used and abused. No exit interview offered, no questions about how to improve care and staff experience. Gave us a cart of vending machine foods as a nice gesture for working through the pandemic.

pros: I liked some of my coworkers. Many people are trying to make this place better.

job_title: Multi Skilled Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: I have just started at Mount Carmel East, but all of the staff have been very welcoming during my training! Most of the employees that I have worked with seem adept at their jobs and a have a drive to provide quality healthcare. Floor managers (Unit manager, Nursing manager) genuinely care about the employees on 3 Tower. I was just granted a weeks vacation with only giving a month notice because I had just started, but the unit manager made it work so that I could take those dates off. PTO accumulates quickly as well.
cons: Pay could be better, they are starting me out at $11.74/hr. There are shift differentials: $1.00* on the weekends, and I believe $2.50* after midnight (*these are Tech differentials, not sure about other positions). Benefits aren't the greatest and retirement here is marginal. The Mount Carmel healthcare system isn't the most prestigious in Central Ohio.

pros: Coworkers are amazing and are what make it tolerable

pros: Great, until my job was eliminated.
cons: Job was eliminated. Didn't see that coming.

pros: Meeting new people, learning about different types of isolations, Working alongside Nurses, Doctors , Techs, Moving up the ladder alot of oppurtunities,  Able to go to school through them after you been employed for 9 months.
cons: Not having enough employees to fulfill company needs, lack of  communication with co-workers and management, Doing others work because the Nurses get lazy or another hospital worker, Over worked at times / Understaffed,  Certain workers treat housekeepers like they're beneath them, Individuals not following certain protocols when disposing something in a patient room. Like leaving IV bags with medicine still in the IV medicine, not removing Urinal cups out of room, leaving fecal in toilets or bowls until a housekeeper arrives, Not removing food trays especially if it's it's just sitting it creates a landing dock for bugs. Putting their work on others and housekeepers moving beds and that should be left up too patient transport. We already do enough.  Should be paid more we do a lot. Eventually you'll get tired it's just crazy. Makes me not even wanna to do Housekeeping anymore.

pros: Direct care staff are wonderful and caring. Adequate equipment and supplies available for direct care staff. Schedulers are very helpful.
cons: Management micromanages. The physical therapist managers have no clue how important most aspects of OT are, especially during "real life" practice/treatment sessions. Much favoritism is extremely evident. Inconsistently ensure staff follow protocol to the T.

pros: They do want to invest in each person, and have great benefits. They always say that if you leave you will come back because of the huge culture shock. MCHS is a faith based facility and I would recommend working here to anyone, I've just outgrown my options and needed to expand.
cons: Onboarding and precepting on the units varies. It's hit or miss. Allow the clinical educators to do it so it can be a standardized mix of patient care with technology training. It blends process with function. The best of both worlds to be successful.

pros: There are genuinely a few good people there.
cons: Poor management, executive director is a physical therapist who only cares about the money and bottom line, not what is in the patients best interest. Unrealistic expectations, poor understanding of what is being asked of the direct caregivers. They have incompetent people "case managing" who never see the patient and do not work well as team players. Keep asking more and more with little giving back in return. No one is happy there and most are looking for something else. Lack of support from management and administration. RUN, don't walk away from this company as quick as you can.

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Westerville, OH
pros: Started working there 4 years ago and I have changed positions twice. I have had over $5 in raises since I started there. I work three 12 hour shifts and have the rest of the week off. Upper management is wonderful to work with.
cons: The hospital is short staffed most of the time meaning you are taking responsibility for more patients than the average hospital around here. strict dress code that makes the hospital a bit boring. In my unit and position there is exactly enough employees to cover all the shifts so there is very little done if your work schedule conflicts with life outside of work.

pros:
Managers work around scheduling needs if you are a good employee.
Vision and dental are pretty good, medical needs improvement.
cons: At the time I was employed there they ran my department through a contract service and it was horrible. The company did not care about the Mount Carmel employees  You can't just go to HR you have to set up and appointment so the vibe is the hospital does not care about the employees. When some of the employees went to the hospital with their issues the hospital held a gather of the department and said they fully support the contract service.

review_title: Started as a great facility that had a meaningful purpose but lost its soul.
pros: Great place to hone nursing skills, assessment skills and time management.  Beautiful new facility to work in
cons: Staffing, not being supported by upper management, management is NOT consistent with when policy is to be followed vs. When to do what is "told" by management or physician.  The ZeroHarm (toward patients) program immediately goes to wayside if there is a cheaper option--i.e.  charge rn with full team, increasing ratios, while decreasing support staff.

job_title: RN Med/Surg Orthopedic in New Albany, OH
pros: Nice and clean unit to work on.  Free coffee and benefits were ok. Good reputation and room to advance.
cons: I worked at the New Albany surgical hospital on the recovery floor and honestly I hated it from day one.  The staff was very cold and unfriendly.  I never felt welcomed nor did anyone step in to help me.  Staff members talk about each other, gossipy and they will throw you under the bus in a second.  It never happened to me but I saw it happen to many others.

review_title: There are much better places in Columbus
pros: Flexible scheduling, generous paid time off, reasonably good benefits, management is fairly down to earth and approachable.
cons: Extremely heavy workload, pay is low compared to OSU and Ohio Health. Mount Carmel does not reward loyalty. Pay raises actually decrease the longer you are there. They cut the evening and night shift differentials dramatically--without notice. Mount Carmel West is old and almost embarrassing. It doesn't feel like a health organization that is going anywhere, unlike the others in Columbus. I'm seriously considering leaving after over 10 years there.

review_title: Great place for new graduate RNs, terrible for everyone else
pros: Good benefits, good pay, newly updated facilities
cons: Terrible management, toxic work environment, troubled reputation

job_title: Patient Financial Services in Columbus, OH
pros: pay is nice and was close to my house
cons: The nurses would sit around and talk loudly about the patients, some nurses were on drugs (I remember they were all talking about going to some bar after work and they invited me and they were all doing drugs,) the nurses are so mean to the patients. I worked in the ER and we had a lot of patients that were homeless and would just want somewhere to sleep. The nurses were cruel to them. Just check them in, they have insurance so why are you so worried about them? Just an awful and dirty place.

pros: Mount Carmel Health System is a wonderful company to work for. They support their nurses in achieving nursing excellence; continuing education, EBP awareness and integration into practice, safe patient care practices. They value work/life balance and that it essential to life!! Physicians are some of the nicest I have ever worked with they truly care.
cons: As with many healthcare companies, sometimes there are changes in management that cause hurdles and bumps in the road.

pros: Although you get a lot of PTO days, there are only 6 paid holidays. Insurance is average for similar health systems in that you must use Mount Carmel physicians.
cons: 401k match program leaves much to be desired. They do not do much at all for employee engagement, which is probably why overall employee satisfaction is so low, at least in the corporate back office areas. Incorporate business areas, many employees tend to stay in their positions for 20+  years, so there is little opportunity for movement until they retire and it makes them very resistant to any sort of change, which can be very difficult for any newcomers.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: Weekend pay. Shift differential. Covertly aggressive vs overtly rude (helps atomosphere not feel as toxic as it could be). Lots of down-time. People get along between the petty and / or fakeness. Can be fun depending on who you are and your personality.
cons: Gossip culture. Some pharmacist are REALLY rude and obnoxious. Pharmacist dont know much about what the techs actually do, how to help, or what role does what. lots of lifting. May end up doing more than one techs job quite frequently. Employees see training as an opprotunity to do nothing. Be willing to learn as you go and be called incompetent for it.

job_title: License Practical Nurse in Grove City, OH
pros: Took me on as a new hire after buying out my doctors practice.  Told I would be doing my same job. Had hard time learning the EMR because everyone had a different way of showing you. I was fired after 90 days saying I had as much training as everyone else( which I didn't)  . I was just older and had a harder time catching on. I asked for more training , but it was denied .i
cons: Learning the computer system. Getting into a routine. Different ways to do computer system was confusing. Also understand older persons may need more training, don't just fire them.

pros: Teamwork is fabulous when there is time...I really enjoyed most of my coworkers. I like the Subway at East. Not much else to say that would be considered a pro.
cons: The staffing ratios in the ED are unsafe at East. The patients are very sick and some require lengthy one on one nursing care. There is no one else to care for your other patients while you are with the sickest of the sick; everyone else is in the same situation. The turnover rate is staggeringly high, yet nothing is done about it. I cannot believe that the CNO and CEO are not in there finding out why this is happening! Nurses at other hospitals know Mt Carmel's reputation and make negative comments about it. There is distinct favoritism at East ED. Some people get away with everything, do nothing, and run the show. I worked at two different Mt Carmel facilities and I cannot believe they are even within the same health system! West is organized and runs like a well-oiled machine, while East is a nightmare! The nurses on the floors are exceptionally rude to one another and are constantly writing nurses from other departments up for comical, childish reasons. Everyone is miserable, run down, and because of this, hateful to each other and sometimes to patients. Sometimes there isn't the proper equipment to do your job. East ER is no place for new grads or inexperienced nurses, however, they are hired because no one else with a brain is applying there.

review_title: Mt.Carmel St.Anne's a great place to work
pros: I had a thorough orientation that was not rushed,  continuous education and opportunities to learn, caring environment, self scheduling, health benefits, an atmosphere of respect. An open door to my manager and director to voice concerns or problems.
cons: the only cons were cons that couldn't really be helped...ie. a crazy day with a lot of sick people!  More hours for the cafeteria to be open!

review_title: Worked for Mt. Carmel for 5 years, in multiple different positions.  Overall, had a very good experience.
pros:
-Worked with wonderful people
-Felt cared for by management, not just another employee
-Actually made friends with co-workers
-Good benefits, but mainly only for employee
cons:
-Felt that I reached a ceiling in ability to grow and move up in administration, and only after having graduated from school a couple years before.
-Felt that young age was detrimental in obtaining a position despite more experience than the person selected
-Pay was not very competitive.  Can't complain about getting a paycheck, but nothing was done to entice me to stay.

review_title: Worked at Mount Carmel almost 10 years!
pros: The benefits were good and I had a great manager and great co-workers. Time off accrued per paycheck as opposed to a lump sum once a year. I have to say though that I am little biased because most of my positives come from the experience I endured within my department and not from Mount Carmel as a company. I stayed as long as as did truly because my manager was such a wonderful person and having a manager that goes to bat for you is a rarity these days! However I am grateful to have worked there for the time I was there.
cons: Those who hold positions that are non-clinical (not nurses or doctors) or those not in a management type position are treated inferior when it comes to compensation and employee incentives. The raise infrastructure is garbage, as I worked there almost 10 years and literally made only a few dollars more than I did when I started. The new raise policy put into place in 2012 I believe, had people who just started working there able to receive a higher raise than someone who had been there multiple years. They do promote company advancement to higher positions but like many other companies it's not what you know, it's who you know.

review_title: Great Place to Serve in Mission Mindedness
pros:
Mission, Vision, Guiding Behaviors
Best Sterile Processing Department in Ohio 
Janet Meeks best President encouraging innovative thinking, accountability within a Just Culture
Investing in employees recognition and encouraging to pursue excellence
cons: New management after Janet left changing culture to $$ only.  Focus on bottom line - new Directors  focused on bottom line, targeting older experienced near retirement employees--   to leave organization hire newer younger leaders

job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good people, strong ethical background, most people genuinely enjoy providing help for others, adding to presence in Central Ohio, Nurse-to-patient ratios are pretty poor.
cons: Wages not even with market for Central Ohio (although they claim it to be), Disorganization on many management levels, Financials are currently in the tank.

review_title: Great Place for Leaders to Grow
pros: Leadership works as a team, very family-like atmosphere.  Senior Leadership very supportive of growth and development and helping us do the best we can each day.  Everyone at ever level of this organization puts the patients first!  Love the spiritual culture of our Catholic Health System.
cons: Too many initiatives and priorities.  Not much depth of leadership at the unit level with only one, or in some cases, no assistant managers.

job_title: Health Information Specialist in Columbus, OH
pros: Mount Carmel has been in the Columbus area a very long time and is continually working on projects to expand to new locations. Generally the staff is very helpful and friendly.
cons: The mission statement of Mount Carmel is to provide assistance to those that need it. That seems to directly conflict with the reduction of their West hospital to a smaller barebones facility which is located in downtown Columbus.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: Co workers are supportive and welcoming
cons: Managers are driven by yearly bonus.  Therefore this means they will at all cost avoid spending money even for things as basic as carpet cleaning.  Lack of education requirements for management leads to many ill equipped supervisors and poor decision making.

pros:
•Friendly community 
•Easy access and location (compared to other hospitals in the area)
•Nice facility + expanding 
•Easy to make friends (if you are sociable)
•Room for advancement(certain departments have more opportunity than others)
cons:
•Lowest paying hospital in the area.
•Policies and procedures I think need revamp
•Poor communication between departments 
•A lot of employees I think are lazy and like to put off tasks onto other people
•Security doesn't carry firearms

pros: Community health system with multiple locations, small hospital feel. Many bright nurses and ancillary staff. Opportunities to interact with nursing students and medical residents
cons: Management not connected with employees, often worked short staffed with little plan for long-term relief. Staff education disorganized, schedulers and educators not working together to provide educational offerings for each shift. Benefits/insurance package not competitive with other health systems in area

review_title: Horrible leadership that allows employees to be treated poorly by upper management. HR here is a joke. Unreal!
pros: Hours. That's about all I can think of
cons: Leadership because they set the culture and they allow anything and everything to happen to employees with zero reporcussions. They try to hide the truth and will fire you if it fits their agenda at the time. I truly can't say anything positive about the experience at this organization.

review_title: Easily one of the worst hospitals to work for in Columbus, Ohio.
pros:
Healthcare providers really care about people.
Healthcare providers are usually kind and caring.
Co-workers make a great support team.
cons:
-The Technology is the worst in the metropolitan area. 
-No planning past 2-3 months.
-The lower level of the corporation takes a huge weight of the company and whatever mistakes or lack of planning upper management makes.
-Constantly decreasing wages, benefits and personnel of the lower levels, effectively making them work more and harder for less.
-Faith based - which means it's full of bias and values that they don't follow.

review_title: Great place to work is all about personal attitude!
pros: There are a lot of caring people who work here. The pay is moderate. Everyone helps each other accomplish our goal: quality care of our patients.
cons: The pay is less than some places. Staffing issues arise from lack of compensation for the task at hand. Educational assistance is lacking. Need a work only on weekends program.

review_title: Sr Director, Operational Excellence & Quality Control
job_title: Senior Director, Operational Excellence in Columbus, OH
pros: The company has a great reputation in the community providing Medicare Advantage health insurance products in a large portion of Ohio and MediGold is growing. There are a lot of people who have worked here for a long time, demonstrating that it is a good place to work.
cons: It is sometimes difficult to keep up with the growth and hire experienced people for new or open roles.

pros:
Great teamwork philosophy, people help each other out
Pay (compare to other hospitals and retails)
Friendly environment
It's really hard to get fired unless you screw up multiple times
Faith-based if you are Catholic, but they don't convert anyone
cons:
The building looks old
Communication not always clear
Some coworkers are just incompetent, and it's really hard to fire them, you got so many chances

pros: Great organization with a strong emphasis on career advancement and high quality patient care. I am very impressed with the associates but also the physicians who practice at MCHS.
cons: There are not many things that I find as a downside for working at Mount Carmel Health System. I have overall been very impressed.

pros: It is the utmost rewarding and exciting job I have experience in my 25 years in the medical field .. I work with very passion people and my surgeons or amazing to work for .
cons: The job can be very stressful and laboring on the body. To standing hours at a time Pulling and  lifting patents and equipment . Sometimes you can feel unappreciated.

review_title: Good flexibility of hours but hard work not appreciated
job_title: Patient Financial Specialist in Columbus, OH
pros:
Good benefits
Variety of hours available to fit any schedule

cons:
Hard work not acknowledged 
Management worried about petty issues like gossip more then work related issues
Under staffed in currect department

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: Paid time leave, tuition reimbursement, (sometimes) flexible hours, family oriented, good benefits, advancement opportunities
cons: Short staffed a majority of the time, low pay rates, out of touch management, lack of teamwork, high turnover, impatient patients and ungrateful patients, bothersome family members, employer only cares about nurses primarily

job_title: Staff RN Mount Carmel West in Columbus, OH
pros: Friendly direct patient care staff.
cons: CNO threatening, "knee jerk" reaction, recruits within for management and other administrative positions based on being personal friends not based on qualifications, no consistency.

pros: Many opportunities for new grad nurses to gain experience in the hospital setting.
cons: High turn over and many new grad nurses at this time.  Wages and benefits are not as competitive as other hospital facilities in Columbus, Ohio.

pros: Colleagues are  kind and often supportive of each other.
cons: No matter what you do, as an employee, you will have to work with Human Resources.  As other reviewers have said,  Human Resources is at base, corrupt.  It creates a network of deception.  It will change your pay, it will change your contract, it will make frequent "mistakes" in your compensation.  It will retaliate and ignore you if you question them. You will have to FIGHT for every penny that you already earned.  It's just not worth it.

review_title: Patient Financial Specialist - Decent job,  not a career
job_title: Patient Financial Specialist I in Columbus, OH
pros:
Fast paced work
not necessarily stressful
decent pay
I have nice managers and coworkers
cons:
Not the best pay or benefits
don't intend to stay with the company because of pay/benefits
Must collect a certain amount of co-pays/month
changed a purely registration job into collections

review_title: Don't walk run from this Hospital
job_title: Patient Financial Service Representative in Grove City, OH
pros: 12 hour shifts offered in the Emergency Department
cons: I've worked with the company for a length of time and I can say without a doubt it is the worst place I have ever had to work and endure. The work environment is toxic due to the supervisors favoritism. Supervisors give special privileges to their friends, this includes leaving early, clocking out no lunch, promotions, vacation, etc. If you're on their favorite list or work in outpatient you'll like the job and it can be very rewarding and interesting. However, if you work the ED you'll have to do your work and the other departments. You are expected to cover other departments, meaning you do your work and you do theirs. You also will have to cover other departments lunches, which leaves your department short staffed and not able to eat. I've worked multiple times and seen this, someone on a 12 hour shift will have to wait hours to eat because outpatient needs to be covered. If we try to clock out without a lunch (because we are never usually able to eat or take a full 30 minutes) you're threatened with occurrences and write ups, so we often we work 30 minutes for free. The ED is often short staffed and has to cover the other end of the hospital along with our own duties. You are left alone or work alone for hours at a time, often hungry and needing to use the bathroom. If their is a hole in the schedule you'll work alone. Your supervisor will not come in, will not help you, will not answer your call. We are discouraged and told to never reach out, call or text management with any issues. Working for Mount Carmel in general is bad, terrible benefits that are extremely expensive, raises are based on supervisors opinions and even with a good review are barely more then 10 cents, no room for growth unless you are a favorite. If there was an opportunity the supervisors in this department black ball you so you're DOA, no swag ever, no appreciation from the hospital or hazard / hero pay. HR will tell you to your face you signed up for this so you do not deserve anything. It's a cold and depressing place to work, everything is always broken, the computers are ancient as well as the programs, do yourself a favor and stay away. Look to one of the good hospitals with a good reputation, this is not one of them

job_title: Provider Service Specialist Medigold in Columbus, OH
pros: If I could think of a reason I would tell you
cons: Pay is POOR for what they expect. The healthcare package is insulting, worse than the pay you will be receiving. Very poor management structure. If you do not know anyone you will go nowhere, unless you are a major kiss-up. If their is such a thing as a modern day concentration camp, this is it.

pros: very easy job, don't want to do something, just contract it out
cons: weak management, lower pay than other area hospitals, cuts to benefits every year

pros: I liked most of the people I worked with. Benefits are pretty good. Salary is ok, has some good programs for the poor but is moving out of a depressed area to create more $
cons: Managers and leadership can do anything they want to employees and get away with it.  Poor teamwork. Never hear thank you or a nice word from my manager. Problem managers are moved around from department to department instead of fired. Not enough diversity

pros: Enjoyed coworkers learned alot with old management  there are really no pros at one time there was
cons: New Directors that they hire are liars and are micomangers which is why they are failing you have rn that are at a 6 to 1 which is why they won't place ever do not work here ever it is dangerous for patients and your license that you worked hard for benefits keep changing not for the better

pros: The staff is pretty friendly, it is nice to know the CEO and he know you by name. a family atmosphere.
cons: African-Americans are under-represented in leadership. Mt Carmel doesn't invest enough in its greatest asset: its people, by not giving the tools necessary to do the jobs well.

pros:
Faith based organization
Doctors are pretty cool and actually know what they are talking about

cons:

Very poor supervision in Radiology Department, they are always in meetings or somewhere and when something happens then they write people up when it could of been prevented.

pros: Person to person interaction learning new things everyday I work it's never the same patients that you are taking care of
cons: Bad management the nurses don't help with the patients you have together there is so much that we have to do and e don't get paid enough

job_title: Flex Choice RN in Columbus, OH
pros: Staff seem oblivious to better opportunities around the corner

pros: Learning opportunities have been available to me.  For most of my journey I've had an engaged mentor. The mission of MC is fantastic and real/evident everyday.

review_title: Depends on what you make of it
